page.title: 13DAIRY FARM, EAST BARKWITH
page.content: One farm specialised in{milk production. It was part of a larger unit, and had no machinery except the milking parlour. It had 58 acres of rough{pasture,}and 60 acres of grass for{silage.}This received a nitrogen feed, and was cut by machinery from one of the other farms. There was a silo for the grass, which was not in use. One stockman managed the 75{cows. In summer,the cows were out to pasture supplemented with cattle cake, and each cow was expected to produce 20 litres milk per day. In winter, the cows were kept in sheds and fed on beet pulp, maize gluten, wheat and silage to yield 12 litres milk per cow per day. The cows were milked,12 at a time, in a herring-bone parlour. Milk was cooled to 30C in a bulk tank, before collection by the Milk Marketing Board tanker.
